SENT.plain: OBJECTIVE: To describe the clinical and serologic findings of 50 antiphospholipid antibody (APA)-positive patients within a retrospective study
METHODS: Measurement of visual acuity, slit-lamp biomicroscopy, tonometry, fundus examination and perimetry
Laboratory tests were performed for detection of APA against thromboplastin and cardiolipin
Antinuclear antibodies (ANA), antibodies to dsDNA, antithyroidal and antiparietal antibodies were also tested
RESULTS: A combination of both transient and permanent visual disturbances was noticed in more than half of the patients
Transient visual disturbances included transient blurred vision, partial defects of the visual fields and amaurosis fugax
The most frequent permanent abnormalities were optic atrophy in 20 patients, due to AION in 9 cases, and disturbances of the choroidal circulation in 17 patients
Fourty-six patients had positive levels of thromboplastin APA; cardiolipin APA were found to be increased in 36 patients
CONCLUSIONS: We did not find a clear correlation between APA activity or the immunoglobulin classes in the individual and the severity of the ocular disease

The benefit from a therapy with the antiplatelet agent acetylsalicylic acid was evident in a reduction of the patients' transient visual disturbances and, in most cases, no further progression of permanent visual field defects was observed
